Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: Exploring Novel Organic Thermoelectric Composites with Hierarchical Architecture and High Figure of Merit

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
The research objective of this Faculty Early Career Development (CAREER) Program project is to synthesize and characterize novel organic thermoelectric composites with hierarchical architecture and high figure of merit for efficient thermoelectric conversion. Thermoelectric conversion involves the conversion between thermal energy and electrical energy. This process can be used for power generation by harvesting various heat sources and it is renewable, reliable, and scalable. The efficiency of thermoelectric conversion is significantly determined by the material's figure of merit. Organic materials hold promise for thermoelectric application due to their attractive features, such as lightweight, abundance, easy processing and environmentally-benign characteristics. However, their current figure of merit is very low, and significantly hindered their potential applications. In this work, original chemical and physical processing methods will be developed to synthesize novel hierarchical organic composites. The process-structure-property relationship will be investigated to tailor the hierarchical architecture for high figure of merit. The interfacial structure and thermoelectric behavior will be theoretically and experimentally investigated to understand carrier transport in the hierarchical composites, and then expand the limits of phonon and electronic transport for exceptional thermoelectric properties.

If successful, the results of this research will enable a new method to design and synthesize nanostructures for desired bulk properties. The expected results will also result in a new class of organic thermoelectric materials for efficient thermoelectric conversion, and lay a foundation for harvesting renewable energy. The educational plan, which will be closely integrated with research efforts, will: (1) launch a new program for training engineering students with interdisciplinary knowledge and skills; 2) stimulate young students to pursue careers in science and engineering; 3) recruit and mentor minority students on cutting-edge nanotechnology research.

ProgramReference.Text: REU SUPP-Res Exp for Ugrd Supp

POR.DRECONTENT:
Zero-dimensional fullerene and two dimensional graphene can be assembled into hierarchical hybrid nanostructures via either covalent or non-covalent assembly process. Non-covalent assembly more favors the electronic transport. The hierarchical nanostructure of fullerene and graphene could generate synergistic effect on carrier mobility and charge concentration. On the other hand, the host materials can also significantly impact the thermoelectric properties. For example, graphene-fullerene filled epoxy resin shows inferior thermoelectric properties while graphene-fullerene filled conjugated polymers shows superior thermoelectric properties. In additional, the ratio between fullerene and graphene can also affect the electrical conductivty and thermal conductivity of the hybrids composites. In addition, the ratio of fullerene and graphene can also engineer the bandgap of graphene, and thus achieve a novel nanostructure with tunable bandgaps. Such tunable bandgaps can also affect the Seebeck coefficient of the composite since the barrier between polymer hosts and fillers can filter low-energy charges. Optimal ratio could help to acheive high electrical conductivity, high Seebeck coefficient, and hindered thermal conductivity. As a result, tailored fullerene and graphene assembly structures and polymer host mobility could help to achieve high-perforamnce thermoelectric materials for practical application. Therefore, the results and discovery result in a new class of organic thermoelectric materials for efficient thermoelectric conversion, and lay a foundation for harvesting renewable energy.

The research was also integrated with educational activities, and this proejct help to train and provide workforce in the material processing and engineering field. More than 10 undergraduate and 4 graduate students have been invovled in the reserach activites. Most of them are working in the functional materials and manufacturing field, including both industry and academia. The discovery from this project was also incorporated into outreach activities with elementary and middle school, and many young stuents are inspired to choose science and engineering as their future careers.

Modified by: Shiren Wang

In additional, the ratio between fullerene and graphene can also affect the electrical conductivty and thermal conductivity of the hybrids composites. In addition, the ratio of fullerene and graphene can also engineer the bandgap of graphene, and thus achieve a novel nanostructure with tunable bandgaps. Such tunable bandgaps can also affect the Seebeck coefficient of the composite since the barrier between polymer hosts and fillers can filter low-energy charges. Optimal ratio could help to acheive high electrical conductivity, high Seebeck coefficient, and hindered thermal conductivity. As a result, tailored fullerene and graphene assembly structures and polymer host mobility could help to achieve high-perforamnce thermoelectric materials for practical application. Therefore, the results and discovery result in a new class of organic thermoelectric materials for efficient thermoelectric conversion, and lay a foundation for harvesting renewable energy.
